summary:
China unveiled a wide array of new weapons at a major military parade today, a visible change in Beijing’s public posture that Western officials say is intended to signal growing military strength. The parade coincided with high-profile diplomacy in Beijing, where Russian President Vladimir Putin met North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, and with Russian praise for North Korean fighters reportedly deployed to Ukraine, a claim observers say needs independent confirmation. These developments deepen questions about regional security calculations and will likely prompt capitals in East Asia and Washington to reassess force posture and diplomatic strategies; expect renewed consultations among allies and possible sanctions or arms-control responses in the coming weeks. Analysts will watch closely for changes in force posture or joint exercises.

Other major items were humanitarian and regulatory. Afghanistan suffered an aftershock after a quake that has killed at least 1,400 people and left thousands trapped, with rescuers deploying helicopters, BBC World reports. In Darfur a landslide killed at least 1,000 people and much of the area remains inaccessible to the UN and aid groups, Al Jazeera says. In policy, a U.S. antitrust ruling lets Google avoid breakup but forces data-sharing with rivals, a change likely to affect markets and competition rules. The IAEA’s finding of uranium at an alleged Syrian site and a U.S. strike on a drug-laden vessel near Venezuela raise arms-control and regional-security concerns; access and aid must be secured within days to limit further harm.

headlines.title: China unveils new weapons at parade, signaling military strength
headlines.summary: BBC World says Beijing displays a range of military hardware as a parade show of power to Western powers; observers say the display could influence regional security calculations.

headlines.title: Afghanistan hit by strong aftershock after quake kills at least 1,400
headlines.summary: BBC World says thousands remain trapped under rubble as rescuers deploy helicopters in remote areas hit by the quake and subsequent landslides.

headlines.title: Sudan appeals for aid after landslide kills at least 1,000 in Darfur
headlines.summary: Al Jazeera English reports much of the affected region remains inaccessible to the UN and aid groups, hindering relief efforts and increasing humanitarian needs.

headlines.title: Peru government says Indonesian embassy official shooting in Lima likely a contract killing
headlines.summary: Peru's government says the killing appears to be a contract killing, underscoring diplomatic tensions and prompting calls for a thorough investigation.

headlines.title: Trump confirms U.S. strike on drug-laden vessel near Venezuela
headlines.summary: Trump says the U.S. has struck a drug-laden vessel after it left Venezuela, signaling ongoing enforcement efforts in the Caribbean.

headlines.title: Putin thanks Kim for North Koreans fighting in Ukraine
headlines.summary: BBC World reports thousands of North Korean soldiers are thought to have died fighting for Russia in Ukraine, illustrating a controversial regional proxy dynamic.

headlines.title: Google avoids break-up but must share data with rivals
headlines.summary: BBC World reports the U.S. antitrust ruling lets Google avoid a breakup while requiring data sharing with competitors, a decision watched by tech policymakers.

headlines.title: IAEA finds uranium at alleged Syrian nuclear site from al-Assad era
headlines.summary: Al Jazeera English reports the IAEA found uranium at a site suspected of Syria's covert nuclear program, urging Damascus to cooperate fully with investigations.

headlines.title: Putin and Kim meet in Beijing as Kremlin says Russia not plotting against US
headlines.summary: Al Jazeera English reports Putin and Kim meet in Beijing; the Kremlin says Russia has no plans to plot against the United States, aiming to project regional diplomacy.
